patterns: How do I use you
How do you work
responses: Unfortunately, I'm a simple bot prone to mistakes. However, if you ask the right questions, I should provide answers to most of your basic questions. If I don't respond or if I give the wrong answer, try asking the question another way. I work best with direct questions such as **How should I get started?**. Try to avoid story questions such as **I've been studying Japanese for over a year and feel I have a good foundation. What might be the best way to get started with such a situation?**. These long story questions confuuse me so please try and think of the most direct way to ask me your question. Thank you!

What is SRS
What is spaced repetition system
what does anki do

What is anki study
responses: Anki is the recommended SRS to use with Refold. SRS stands for " Spaced repetition system". SRS are basically flashcards that use an algorithm that attempts to show you information just before you forget them, rather than entirely randomly. This makes studying material much more effective and efficient. Anki is recommended because of the many powerful tools for language learning that make it the best option out there. I recommend you check out the resources below from Refold to learn more about Anki and how it works.
Field-1: This article goes over the SRS and why we use it for language learning
Field-2: This covers the basics of Anki and how to use it.
intents.Related-Q: Do I have to use Anki?

patterns: Do I have to use Anki
Do I need to use Anki
Do I need to use SRS
is anki nessesary
do i have to usue an srs
is srs nessesary
Is Anki necessary
is srs necessary
What if I don't want to use SRS Program
Should I use Anki
responses:
In the end, Anki is just a supplement to the actual method. The primary and most crucial part of Refold is immersion. Anki is just there to help prime words and get them on your radar to make them easier to fully acquire during immersion. Many people have become fluent without ever using Anki or SRS programs.

With that being said, we recommend using Anki. Learning a language is a long journey, and we genuinely do believe that with Anki, the process will go a little faster. If you find Anki a terrible part of the process, then try not going so hard with it. Even 5 words or less a day can help. Just pick a manageable number for yourself and go with it. Even 5 a day is better than nothing and should keep your review time low and manageable.
Field-1: This video goes in detail about why we use the SRS and how to best use it
Field-2: This article goes over some best ways to use the SRS

Backlog of anki reps
Anki backlog
how do I handle an Anki backlog
responses:
It is not recommended that you restart a deck. Instead, follow the advice in the article linked below on catching up if you have many built-up reviews.

The reason for this is that even though you won't remember many of the cards, many you will remember. If you start over, you will have to start those known cards fresh, which is a big waste of time. It's better to slowly work through your backlog of due cards. This way, your known cards stay where they are, and forgotten cards begin to refresh.

With that said, if you wish to restart your deck, the best way is to delete the deck and load it in fresh. This ensures all cards are in the intended order (Make sure you still have access to the fresh Anki deck before deleting the old one). You can also select cards from the Anki browser and right-click them, selecting "reschedule..." and sending them to the back of the card queue. This likely will shuffle the cards into a different order than you desired, though, so it isn't preferred.
Field-1: Refold article on how to catch up with a large amount of due cards.
Field-2: This short video goes over how to reset cards if you absolutely must. This is not recommended

How many anki cards should i do a day
recommended number of cards per day for JP1K
how much time should i spend per day on anki
responses:
Anki is a supplement to immersion. Many people get into the trap of thinking more Anki means quicker progress. In reality, it's the balance of Anki to immersion that leads to more rapid progress. The recommended amount of cards per day is 10-20, but less is also acceptable. Also, keep in mind that new words will be harder to learn early in the process because you have nothing to associate new words to. So your early cards per day may be much less. Find a balance that works for you.

**Another way to look at cards per day**
Another way to look at cards per day is to not add a specific amount of cards per day at all. Some have found success in allotting a time for Anki rather than a card count. My personal recommendation is that you should be doing a MAX (less is fine) of 30 minutes of Anki for every 1.5 hours of immersion (for a total of 2 hours) with an Anki cap of 2 hours. So at 3 hours of immersion, you have 1 hour of Anki (4 hours total), and at 6 hours of immersion, you cap out at 2 hours of Anki and just add more immersion beyond this. I like this method because it ensures that you don't cut into immersion time to keep up on your Anki card goal.

If you chose the time method above, it's important to note that you always finish your reps for the day. If you run out of time, finish your backlog of cards, but don't add new cards. If you have time, add as many new cards as you can for that day in the remaining time. I do recommend capping your daily cards, though, at 20-30 max, even if you have time remaining, so you trickle cards out and don't have huge swings in cards per day.

patterns: What should I do about leeches
What do I do if i'm getting a lot of leeches
should I delete leeches
what are leeches
What should I do about leaches
what to do with leech card
responses:
Leeches are what happen in Anki when you mark a card wrong a given amount of times. You set this number in deck options, and once this number of times failed is reached, Anki will either tag or delete the card; however you have it set up. Refold believes that constantly hunting for easy, low-hanging fruit that is within your range to learn is the best and fastest method to chipping away at the language. Because of this, we recommend setting your leeches at 5 and allowing leeched cards to suspend or delete.
Note: Every time you get a card wrong, it goes into a **learning** mode. Marking a card incorrect when in learning mode does not add a counter to the leech number. So if you get a card wrong that day, and then that same day you mark it wrong 10 more times without ever getting it correct, this still only counts as 1 leech counter. Only after you mark it correct, then see it again on a different day, will marking it incorrect add a counter to the leech counter.
Field-1: This video goes over low hanging fruit, the snowball effect and why it's so important to progress as it pertains to leeches and accepting ambiguity

patterns: Is it normal to feel like I can't remember anything after Anki
I feel like Anki does not teach me words
responses: It's normal to feel like words aren't very solidified from Anki. That's because they aren't. Anki's role is to prime words and concepts in your head. But you WILL have a problem remembering those words and concepts outside the SRS. Because the brain is very contextual, it will feel it only needs to remember it when you are using the SRS and have problems recalling outside of it. But, Anki will help get memories started in your brain. To drill in faint familiarity with that vocabulary and concepts so that when you later come across those elements in your immersion, you will be able to acquire them much faster.

patterns: What is morphman
should I use morphman
is morphman good
can i use morephman
is morphman recomended
responses:
**__Thoughts on morphman and the two camps__**

Morphman is an addon for Anki that attempts to find 1T sentences from a sentence bank. Thoughts on this are split.  So I'll go over the pros and cons, and you can make your own choice.

    Pros Camp:
1. It makes sentence mining quick.
2. Perfect for people with not a lot of time
3. Can use frequency list to find useful words easily.

Cons Camp:
1. Time save is an illusion as all-time sentence mining is not immersion (as opposed to finding sentence while immersing)
2. Morphman can be buggy. It often shows you words you have already marked known. Sorting through this wastes more time.
3. Sentence context is not as concrete and leads to a weaker understanding of the word.
4. Once you have a little sentence mining experience, mining in immersion is faster and leads to better sentences.
5. You are often given 2T+ sentences that appear 1T that make the sentence not very high quality to use.

In the end, it's up to you if you use morphman or not. My Creator (Brett) and many in the server don't like using it. He used to live by it and refused to not use it. When it broke on him, he was forced to sentence mine during immersion, and this was the best thing that happened to him. Being forced into it made him realize how much better an experience it is. However, many also disagree with this and enjoy the addon.

Reading lookups and sentence making are possible with the Anki app on and just simple copy paste on iPhone, but for now there is no multimedia card creation tools sadly. Only for android.

(Note: There are always to make it work. On iPhone you can listen to your immersion and try and look up words you don't know just by looking up words by hand in the dictionary. Don't let the tools be the reason you don't continue forward. They are nice, but not nessesary. Get your immersion however you can.

patterns: What should I be doing daily in stage 1

What should my daily routine be

what do I do everyday
responses:
Make sure you check out the resources in <#784120941650509865> as this is answered there in much greater detail than I can cover here. But in short, the goal of stage 1 is to build a foundation. This generally entails 3 daily activities.

**1. Daily Foundation Vocabulary (Anki/flashcards)**
 Slowly work through your vocabulary foundation deck. For more information on foundation vocabulary, ask me "**How do I get a vocabulary foundation**".

**2. Browse Grammar Guide**
For 10-20 minutes a day, you can help jumpstart comprehension by casually browsing a beginner grammar guide. For more info on grammar, ask me "**How should I learn grammar?**".

 **3. Immersion**
 This is the most critical element of the process. You want to immerse at least 3 times more than you do Anki (flashcards). For more info on immersion, ask me "**What do I do when immersing in stage 1**".

responses:
What content to consume is a tricky question to answer and changes based on many things. The article linked below will help you figure things out.

 Beyond reading the related articles, here are some things to help you find content.

1. Always prioritize your interests over any hypothetical, optimal path. The more you are interested in the content, the better your focus engagement will be, which is essential to making gains.

2. The Media share section allows you to ask for recommendations, discuss content you consume, and look through the archive to see what others have recommended. Head on over to <#783082970432536608> to gain access to the media share channels.
3. Finally, check out the community document (linked below) to find content recommendations and resources for all stages.

Stage 1 Note: For people in stage 1, we generally recommend focusing on audiovisual content. Anime can be powerful in this stage as it is often more clearly spoken than natural content. The visuals will help you stay interested and engaged with the content during the early phases while comprehension is low. Also, your ear probably won't even hear much of the language correctly in this early stage. By focusing on audio-based content with visuals to keep you interested, you can train your ear to listen to the sounds of the language. At the same time, you chip away at your foundation vocab and grammar.

Field-2: Refold content document, link to resources for leveled content

Finding content with subtitles can sometimes be challenging. But here are some primary places to try.

**Streaming Services with subs**
Streaming services like Netflix and Animelon have a lot of content with matching subs. You can use tools like "FlixGrab+" (google it) to download content from Netflix, and "Subadub" a chrome and firefox extension to download or select subtitles for easy lookups.

Some content will have Japanese subs available in your country, especially Japanese content that are Netflix originals. But a lot more content will have Japanese subs if you use a working VPN to access Japan Netflix. Check the Refold community document to see which VPN's are currently working.

**Download and find subs / Sub repositories**
Website like Nyaa.si have a lot of Japanese content. Some content will have Japanese subs, but for other content, you will have to find subs. The Refold content and resources community document has a list of subtitle repositories that have subtitle files for thousands and thousands of shows and movies. If the subtitle files don't match, you can check the Tech and Tools document for tools that will help you retime subtitles to fit your media.

**YouTube content**
The majority of YouTube content has computer-generated subs. These can be very inaccurate and should not be trusted very often, but just used as a guide. However, some YouTube content does have human-made subtitles. If the subtitle file says "Japanese" and not "Japanese (auto-generated)", then the subs are probably human-made and can be trusted more. I've linked below a source for finding some human made YouTube subbed content.

** Non-Native Japanese content**
Dubed content subs often don't match. Be careful.

patterns: Is anime bad for learning

my friend said anime is bad for langauge learning, is that true
responses: Learning Japanese from Anime is perfectly fine. There are many reasons for this. First off being, if you enjoy anime, then anything that causes you to enjoy your immersion and be engaged in it is incredibly valuable. On top of that, anime voice actors often speak pretty clearly, making the early stages of immersion easier to understand. That being said, anime often has unique language use that most people would not use so once your comprehension is a high level and you move onto stage 3 for output/speaking, you will want to start engaging with more natural speech. But we'll worry about how to do that once we get there! Until then, enjoy your anime!

how are video games for immersion
responses:
Most video games are not as valuable for language learning because the language density is low. You can also enjoy games without understanding what is being said at all. But if you're gonna spend your time playing games, you might as well do it in your target language. Just don't expect significant language gains from this. The exception are visual novels, and some JRPG's. All games are different though, so use your own judgement. In general you want immersion sources with as much language density as possible. Over time, it really does matter.

That being said, if you are going to play video games, having passive immersion in the background can help. When the game provides little to no active immersion, switching focus to your passive immersion can increase your overall language exposure. It's not as good as language-dense active immersion, but it helps.

What are graded readers

Graded readers
responses:
Graded readers are books and stories that are categorized to attempt to progress through difficulty levels. Graded readers are a fine introduction to reading but aren't necessarily recommended by Refold. We believe you should always prioritize how much you enjoy your immersion over any type of hypothetical, optimal content. If you enjoy the process, you will be more engaged and get a lot more from your immersion.

That being said, some people love graded readers because they can easily find content that they can have a chance of understanding. If that is the case, then feel free to use graded readers in the early stages. But we recommend trying to move away from them as soon as possible. Others, however, enjoy content based on visuals or what little of the story they can understand, even if it's more complicated. Hunting for that low-hanging fruit and listening for the stuff they DO understand is engaging and fun for them. For those types of people, most likely graded readers will not be very useful.

We have some graded readers listed in the comunity doucment (linked below) if you decide you enjoy them.

patterns: What is grammar
responses: Grammar means something different to everybody, but in short, it is the structures and rules that attempt to explain how a language functions. Most people think languages are build from these rules, but, in reality, the rules are created by grammarians FROM language as a way to try and explain how it functions. They look at how language is used and then look for patterns and rules from usage. This is why there are so many acceptions and quirks in grammar rules and why it makes no sense to learn a language like math, where grammar rules are the equations. This does not work.

responses: We don't recommend getting detailed with grammar. Instead, just focus on understanding a general idea of basic grammar concepts and then, like a detective, hunt down usage in your immersion and pay attention to how it's used. Slowly, over a LONG period, these grammar concepts will solidify more and more, eventually understanding every nuance and gaining a 6th sense for their complex acceptions and usage quirks. You can use the Refold Japanese Grammar Primer and the links within that guide as reference and casual grammar browsing.

responses: We don't recommend focusing on these details. Instead, just focus on understanding your immersion. Pay attention to the situation. The relationship between the person talking and who they are speaking to. Over time, you will begin to understand the difference between formal, informal, slang, polite, Keigo, and everything up, down, and in-between. Rather than worrying about the rules of politeness, build a 6th sense for it. This will take a long time. Years and years, but it will happen. Once you are functionally fluent, if there are any grey areas you still can't figure out, you can always ask native Japanese speakers for their input IN Japanese. Until then, don't focus on the things you cant figure out on your own and keep hunting for low-hanging fruit.

patterns: What do I do during immersion
How do I immerse
what should I focus on during immersion
what do I focus on during immersion
How to immerse
how to do active immersion
What do I do for immersion as an absolute beginner
what do i do in immersion
responses:
What exactly you do during immersion is hard to explain. The video linked below attempts to clairify this, but here is the answer in short. Do whatever you have to do to understand what you are consuming. This does not mean stop and look up every word you don't know to try and understand everything you are consuming. This is not advised to do often. This means to focus on the element preventing you from understanding your immersion.

In the beginning, this will be the sounds of the language. When you first start, you won't be able to hear the language properly. Most of it will sound like gibberish, so your focus should be on listening as intently as you can to listen to the sounds of the language. Once you start hearing the sounds better, you will begin to start picking out words. Some of the words you will recognize from your flashcards. Others will just be words you have heard in your immersion a lot and stick out. Words will eventually turn into sentences and into groups of sentences, scenes, and ultimately entire stories.

If you are still confused, try watching the video linked below and ask me some of the related questions. Good luck!

responses:
**__How long will this take? How much should I immerse?__**

The short answer is every day and as much as you can without negatively affecting more essential things in your life, like health, job, relationships, etc. The more detailed answer is.

This is a complicated answer because, in the end, we just don't know. Everyone learns at different rates. It also depends on the quality of your immersion, how well you are at keeping focus, your goals, and many more factors. Assuming you don't speak any other Asian languages, you can assume it will require a significant amount of immersion to reach a high level. That being said, here are some basic benchmarks. (These estimates are a guide only and differ from person to person significantly)

**3 Years to Speaking**
We advise getting at least 3+ hours of active immersion and another 3+ hours of semi-active/passive immersion a day to reach the output stage within 3 years. However, by Refold standards, at this point, your comprehension level will be so high that you will already be at a higher level in the language than most ever accomplish.

**Minimum amount**
We do recommend trying to get a minimum of 2 hours of active immersion a day. Anything 1 hour or less likely won't lead to satisfactory progress in a language like Japanese.

**There is no limit but be careful**
The more you immerse, the faster your progress will be. So if you have time, always opt to get more exposure to the language and hunt down ways to add more immersion time. But don't sacrifice physical or mental health, relationships, your job, and other more important things. Learning a language is excellent, but it won't make your life suddenly perfect. Once you speak the language, you want a life and people to enjoy it with.

responses: The short answer is, there is no such thing as too much immersion. The more immersion you do, the quicker your gains will be. That being said, make sure you have a healthy life outside of immersion. Don't sacrifice more important things like health, safety, relationships, job, future, etc. Learning a language is fantastic, but it won't make your life magically better, so make sure you have a healthy life outside of immersion. But with that being said, assuming the above is being protected, the more, the better.

What is immersion
What's intensive immersion
how to do intensive immersion
intensive immersion
active immerision
What is free-flow immersion
responses: Immersion is simply consuming content in your target language (TL) created by natives for natives. Active immersion is immersion where you are entirely focused with the intent to understand it. Your attention isn't divided between other tasks, but rather you are fully dedicated to understanding the content you are consuming. So watching Anime, Movies, reading novels, light novels, watching YouTube videos, and more, are all examples of active immersion. In Refold, we break active immersion up into two types. **Intensive immersion** and **free flow** immersion. Learn more about active immersion and the two types of active immersion in the articles linked below.

patterns: What is passive immersion
what is semi active immersion
how much passive should I do
how much passive immersion should I do
how much semi active should I do
how much semi active immersion should I do
What's passive immersion
What's passive listening
What's a good active vs passive immersion ratio
How much active immersion compared to passive immerison
How much passive listening should I do each day
responses:
Passive immersion (also sometimes called Semi-active immersion) is any immersion you do when you arent 100% focused on immersion. So this would be immersion when doing laundry, working out, cooking, driving, brushing your teeth. Whatever. The article below goes over passive immersion. But there are two things I want to clarify.

**How much passive immersion should I do?**
You want to do as much passive immersion as you can without sacrificing more important things, such as mental/physical health, safety, relationships, your job, etc. That being said, you NEVER want to sacrifice active immersion for passive. Passive immersion is only something you do when you are unable to do active immersion. 

**Passive immersion is misleading**
Passive immersion is a word created to let people know they can always find ways to fit more exposure to the language in, even if they can't fully focus. But in reality, focus is not binary; it's not on or off, black or white. It's a gradient. Sometimes during active immersion, you will lose focus and drift into passive. Other times during passive, you will focus in and get some active. The main thing is, you want to get as much exposure with as much focus as humanly and safely possible in the moment.
Field-2: Another article touching on passive listening and tools to use for passive listening
intents.Related-Q: What is condensed Audio? // How much should I immerse everyday?

patterns: Is passive immersion effective
how useful is passive immersion
is passive immersion even worth it
Is passive listening important
responses: The short answer is yes. The more nuanced answer is, usually. When learning a language,  you want as much exposure to that language as humanly possible without negatively affecting more important things (like health, job, relationships etc). The higher quality your immersion, the more benefit. But anything is better than nothing. If you just have Japanese on in the background and paying zero focused attention to it at all, then no, it's not likely to give much benefit. But who knows, it might provide some minor benefit. But, maybe for 2 hours you don't pay attention to it, then you have 30 seconds where you do focus on it because there is a lull in whatever you are doing. Well, for those 30 seconds, you basically get **active immersion** or at least semi-active immersion. Every little bit adds up over time. It's just up to you to decide if it's worth the effort and sacrifice. I think the related question will provide some more useful information potentially.
intents.Related-Q: What is Passive immersion?

patterns: How much intensive immersion should I do
what ratio of intensive to free flow should I do
responses:
Intensive immersion is recommended to be a supplement to free flow immersion. While it is a powerful tool, you want to be careful about interfering with the natural acquisition process. Because of this, we recommend 30 minutes of intensive immersion a day. If you feel you want to do more, then go ahead and do more. Just be careful you aren't using intensive immersion as a crutch because you can't accept ambiguity. Even with intensive immersion, accepting ambiguity is an important element of the process.

Another thing to keep in mind, if you have much more passive immersion time than you do active immersion, you may want to do a little bit more intensive immersion during your active immersion and then use your passive immersion as the majority of your free flow exposure. But even if this is the case, make sure you are getting a healthy amount of free flow immersion during your active immersion time as well.

Be extra careful to also not burn out doing too much intensive immersion.

responses:
The central part of the Refold system is immersion. Everything else is supplemental. Because of this, we recommend you immersing the very first day you start learning vocabulary. If you need a few days to learn the system, read the articles and watch the videos available, that is fine. But as soon as you start learning foundation vocabulary and grammar, you want to start immersing.

The video linked below will explain why we recommend immersing so early, even if you don't understand anything. But in short, immersion is where you fully acquire elements that speed up the speed at which you learn and acquire new aspects. Conversely, too much learning without the accompanying immersion to solidify and acquire what you are learning will likely slow down your progress.

How much should I understand while immersing

responses:
There is no amount of your immersion that you "should" understand. We all start at nothing. We all need to train our ears to hear the sounds of the language and won't be able to pick out many of the words we know from our flashcards even. This is normal. So don't worry if you understand anything, don't worry if you can't hear the sounds or the words. Just keep listening and stay focused on the elements preventing you from understanding and train your brain to understand it.

Check out the video linked below for a more detailed explanation of why we recomend immersing from day 1, even if you understand almost nothing. Also try asking me the related questions.

responses:
The answer is different for each stage of the process, so make sure you follow the Refold website's recommended advice. With that being said, here is a short answer. What you chose to read, subtitles, manga, light novels, etc, is up to you. But check related quesitons.

In stage 1, you want to focus primarily on listening. This way, you train your ear to hear the sounds of the language before associating them to the writing system too much. Watching content with Japanese subtitles isn't exclusively considered reading; it is more a hybrid activity providing clues to what you hear. 

In phase 2, if you chose, you can start reading more. Once you decide to start adding more reading, you want to try and keep your reading and listening comprehension levels somewhat even. So if one gets out of sync, spend more time with that activity to keep them about even.

It's also important to keep in mind that interests and goals come into play also. Some care more about reading than listening/speaking and vice versa. So spend time with the activity you care about, just know that too much in one direction, or the other will lead to less skill in the other. Find the balance that works for you. For most people, the recommended ratios and method that Refold lays out should work just fine. What you read and when is up to you. See related qeustions

patterns: What is a good Reading to Listening balance
reading and listening ratio
How do I balance reading and listening
Reading and listening balance
responses:
Once you start reading, which is generally in stage 2, we recommend a 70/30 balance or a 50/50 balance. If one aspect is stronger than the other (for example, if your reading is stronger than your listening), listen 70 and read 30 percent. If the two are somewhat equal in strength, then immerse in a 50/50 ratio.

This assumes that you want to keep listening and reading balanced, which we recommend. Some, however, want to be more listening dominants and care about reading less. In contrast, others want to be more reading dominants and don't care as much about listening. So in that case, you will have to find what balance works for you and your goals.

patterns: What is the most important aspect of immersion
whats the most essential part of immersion
What are the most important parts of immersion
what are the most crutial elements of immersion
responses:
Anybody doing Refold for more than a few months knows that immersion is the most critical element of the process. But what are the most essential aspects of the immersion itself? Here are a couple.

**Focus**
Making sure you are focused on your immersion fully during active immersion is essential. Don't be checking emails, don't be scrolling social media. Engage in and focused on your content to signal to your brain that this is important. It's impossible to stay 100% focused for hours at a time, but the goal should be to be as focused as humanly possible at all times. Even if all you can muster is glazed eyes after work. Anything is better than nothing, but focus is better than anything.

**Give your brain things to figure out - Be curious**
 You want to watch your content with the intent to understand. The content you consume should be interesting to you. You should WANT desperately to understand it. This will make you hunt down for clues of what things mean. Your brain will take these curiosities and continue trying to figure them out in your subconscious even when you aren't immersing. So don't just go into immersion with the intent to check off your immersion boxes for the day. Remind yourself that this is something you want to understand and enjoy, and then try your best to do it. Even if you fail for a long time.

responses:
**English Subtitles/Native language subs**
In the beginning using Native language (NL) subs to help build a daily immersion habit is fine. But immersing with NL subs does not offer much benefit in terms of language acquisition. If your mind is focused on reading, it can't focus on the things it needs to focus on to acquire the language.

**Japanese subtitles**
Follow the recommendation for your stage as laid out in the articles on the Refold website. But in short, we recommend having Japanese subtitles on if you have them early in stage 1 to help provide more information for comprehension during this stage when understanding is low. But starting in stage 2, you will begin to slowly remove this crutch.

responses:
Any audio content is suitable for passive immersion. Podcasts, audiobooks, and even a lot of YouTube content. However, early on, when your comprehension is already low, even when entirely focused, we recommend listening to an audio version of your active immersion content. So once you watch a show, you can turn it into an audio version of the show and listen to it as passive immersion. This gives you more exposure to the vocabulary and concepts you are already learning during active immersion.

The act of taking a show and turning it into a shorter audio version of itself, with all the dead air removed, is referred to **condensed audio**. I have linked to an old video by MattVsJapan below going over condensed audio; however, the method he shows is now outdated. If you check the Tech and Tools document (linked below), newer condensed audio tools streamline the process. There are also condensed audio repositories in the resource and content community document that contain already made audio files for a lot of content (also linked below).

What is immersion
responses: Immersion Learning is the act of learning a language by consuming native content. Meaning for natives by natives. There is a lot more to it than this, so I recommend you check out all the resources in <#784120941650509865> so you can learn the foundations first. It's a lot to take in, so take it slow and be curious.

patterns: is reading important
why is reading important
should I be reading
how important is reading
responses: Reading seems to be where the most significant gains in pure language ability are formed. However, too much reading and not enough listening is thought to have negative ramifications on pronunciation, pitch accent instincts, as well as a natural use of spoken vocabulary over written vocabulary. However, it does seem to speed up the process quite a bit. This is why Refold recommends balancing the two the way we do. Focusing on listening only during stage 1 to build a solid foundation and then working into a more balanced approach in stage 2 so you get the best of both worlds. However, depending on your goals, you can balance this however you want. Some may want to go more listening heavy, while others may enjoy going more reading heavy. This will be influenced both by your goals and what type of immersion you enjoy most.

patterns: Is reading easier then listening
which is easier reading or listening
is it normal for my reading to be better than my listening
responses: I would say yes. For most people, reading is more manageable than listening. The visual cues that reading gives help support comprehension so much that it takes most people much longer to develop solid listening skills than reading skills. However, while you do have to do a significant amount of listening, to a certain extent, reading will improve your listening as well as it will increase how comfortable you are with sentence structures and vocabulary.

patterns: why should I not read first
Why does refold recomend only listening at first
why recomend only listening in stage 1
why does Refold not have you read early on
why don't we read early
why don't we read in stage 1
responses:
Refold recommends focusing on listening first and training your ear to hear the sounds of the language before worrying about reading. There are many reasons for this. I'll touch on them quickly.

1. Gives you time to get a kanji foundation. Decks like the Refold JP1K develop a kanji foundation through exposure to kanji in vocabulary but without testing your ability to read the kanji. This gets you familiar with the building blocks of kanji slowly over time. This gives you time to build that foundation before worrying about putting it to use.

2. Train your ear. Your brain likely can't hear all the sounds of the language when you first start. It takes tons of exposure to the language to even hear it properly, so while you gain a vocab and grammar foundation, it's best to work on building your ability to hear the language since you won't be able to understand what you are consuming anyway. Once you have even a 50 vocab foundation, you will start putting those listening skills to great use.

3. There is some evidence that reading too early can create a link in your mind between the sounds of the language and the writing system. This can cause a slightly lagged listening comprehension experience later on because your brain is always relating it to the writing system rather than just processing the sound. Some believe this "link" can't be undone. But even if it can, it takes a lot of time, so we feel to help avoid this, it's best to get a solid listening foundation before reading.

patterns: What's more important, intensive or free flow immersion
what's better intensive immersion or free flow immersion
Do I have to do free flow and intensive immersion
responses: One isn't better than the other. They both serve a purpose. I will say that intensive immersion should be used sparingly. You definitely want to do at least 5 times more free flow immersion than intensive. Intensive immersion helps you process the language at whatever speed you need to pick out new vocabulary and new concepts. However, it can also make you overthink the language and interfere with the subconscious natural language acquisition process. So while it's important to use intensive immersion to bring attention to new concepts, you want to also make sure you are getting a lot of free flow immersion so you are solidifying the stuff you know into automatic, fully acquired, pure language skill.

patterns: what is the most effective way to immerse
what is the best way to immerse
responses: The best way to immerse is with complete focus. Not checking your phone or thinking about the day. Watch your immersion with the intent to understand it. Try and figure it out like a detective. Pretend that if you can summarize whatever scene properly to a friend, you win a million dollars. Hunt down meaning. NEED and desire to understand the story in front of you. It's this type of focus where language acquisition thrives.

patterns: Why should I immerse
Is immersion useful
do I have to immerse
is immersion worth it
is immersion required
responses:
Immersion is the most essential part of the process. It is through immersion that our subconscious begins to form its instinctual understanding of the language. Seeing vocabulary and concepts repeatedly in new, novel contexts signals to our mind that it is important and should be remembered not just in the context of the SRS but all the time.

You will find that if you don't immerse, you will get vocabulary correct every time in Anki, but then when it comes time to use it, or you see it in a new context, you can't recall it. The brain is VERY context-dependent, so you NEED to give it exposure to all these things you are learning in hundreds and hundreds of contexts. This is just one of the many many reasons why immersion is so important.

Don't fool yourself into thinking study or Anki is where the gains are made. They are a supplement. The true magic is in immersion. Aacquisition of the language.

patterns: Should I learn Pitch Accent
How do I learn pitch accent
When do i learn pitch accent
pitch accent
responses:
This is a complicated question that depends on a lot of things. But here is the basic answer.

 **Stage 1 - basic**
 I recommend just becoming familiar with pitch accent. Understand it as a concept and know what it is to be aware of it as you immerse. This alone will be incredibly valuable even if you don't go any further with it. Such a small investment can really add up over time, so we recommend doing at least this.

 **Stage 1 - A little more**
If you arent feeling overwhelmed, and want to take it a bit further, then I recommend learning the pitch patterns and training your ear to hear them in words. Linked below are resources for learning basics about pitch accent and a website to help do maybe 5-10 min a day of basic pitch listening practice.

 **Stage-2 - If you dare**
 Once you are in stage 2, you can take it a bit further by starting to learn the pitch for the words you are learning in Anki. The most consuming part about learning pitch accent is learning the pitch of the individual words, so starting to test the pitch of a word in the SRS is something you can start in stage 2. Don't worry about adding this extra level of difficulty earlier. The words you learned up till now are so common they should be easy to fill in later. 

 **Stage 3 - Ready to Output**
 In stage 3, once you are ready to start outputting, you can get more serious about pitch. Head on over to <#781673820544172034> and ask how to level up your pitch accent when starting to output.

patterns: How long does it take to start understanding anime
how long does it take to learn Japanese
how long does it take to be fluent
how long does Refold take
how long does learning Japanese take
how long before I can understand Youtube
how long before I can understand slice of life
how long before I can understand
how long does it take
What is my expected time to learn japanese
When will I be able to start speaking Japanese
When can I start speaking
when will i be fluent
how long till i'm fluent
how long does it take to get fluent
responses:
It is complicated to answer how long it takes before you understand the language or become fluent. It depends on so many things. How much you immerse, your natural ability, how much time you invest, how focused and how quality the time you spend is, and more. For things like slice-of-life anime, if you immerse a lot in it, it will be quite manageable for you long before fast-paced, mumbled YouTube videos or complex comedy skits. 

My advice is this. Don't focus on how long it will take. Instead, focus on investing time per day. Make that time quality. Stick to it and enjoy your immersion. No matter who you are, it will take a long time to reach a high level in your language. And no amount of worrying about it will make it go faster. So let go of expectations and requirements, investing the time, enjoying that time, making that time focused quality time, and let the progress unfold as it does. The only thing I can promise is, immersion learning is the best way to reach a high, natural level in the language.

For some rough benchmarks, ask me the related question below so you can figure out a very rough benchmark on time to progress relation.
intents.Related-Q: How much should I be immersing per day?

patterns: what is keigo
responses: Keigo is the name for incredibly polite speech in Japanese. Until you are fluent, I wouldn't worry about precisely what Keigo is and instead focus on understanding your immersion. Over time you will gain instincts for what is polite and what is not. Once you are functionally fluent in Japanese, if there are still details of politeness levels that you don't understand, you can ask a Native Japanese speaker IN Japanese. But until then, focus on grasping the low-hanging fruit.

patterns: Should I take a college class to learn japanese
should I take a Japanese class
should I take a Japanese course at school
are japanese classes worth it
responses: This is really up to you. What I can say is, most Japanese classes teach skill-based language learning rather than going with an immersion style language learning method. This generally leads to more unnatural Japanese ability and requires you to pass tests and do grammar drills. All things we feel are useless and even detrimental to the language learning process. However, if you NEED to take a Japanese class, we recommend that you immerse as much as you can in your free time to help counter act some of the negative effects this "skill based language learning" can have.

patterns: What is more important memory or immersion
What's more important, memory or immersion
Memory vs. Immersion
responses: I don't qutie 100% understand this question. Immerison and memory arent relateable things. It helps to have a good memory, but even if you have a bad memory, you can learn a language and immersion will help you acomplish it.

patterns: what is FAQ1
What is FAQ#1
What is FAQ 1
responses:
As a general rule, we try not to answer most questions like "what does X mean", "What is the difference between A and B" and other variations on this in the discord. Many of us truly believe that the "accept the ambiguity" advice of the Refold website is really important. We highly recommend you do your best to constantly hunt for low-hanging fruit. Sentences that with minimal effort (a quick dictionary search) you can understand easily. The faster you can train your brain to let go of things out of your reach and keep hunting for this low hanging fruit, the quicker you will make progress. Don't obsess over why something is the way it is; just accept it and continue trying to figure it out over time as you get more examples through additional input.

It's great that you have questions. But discord/other learners is not where you find answers to those questions. Immersion is where you will find answers to those questions. It's a mindset that will pay dividends as you continue on your journey. Once you brain is primed with a question, it will hunt for the answer in immersion and result in an instinct for the language that no grammar guide, no language learner, and often even, no native Japanese speaker could ever properly explain to you. So, you'll see this a lot, "the answer is immersion". "Acquire" the language, don't "learn" it.

Note: This applies to any questions about language function. "How are A and B different? How are A and B the same? Why is A this way. Why isn't B this way." Whatever modification to the same exact idea you can think of, the answer is the same. "Immerse more".

This is not because we don't want to answer your question. This is because, it's better for YOU that we don't. Happy immersing ðŸ™‚

responses: I can't help you with this. What I can say is, I think you should not worry about this and instead focus on understanding your immersion. The first step, above all else, is slowly chipping away at the language to understand it. Don't worry about writing, speaking, etc., until you have high comprehension first. The goals of stages 1 and 2 of Refold are understanding the language. Then, in stage 3, we can worry about speaking and writing.

patterns: How can I sound native

responses: This is a very challenging, long road if this is your goal. While obtaining a native level is a goal most will not achieve, I can say that if you follow the Refold method, you will get as close as you are capable of achieving. Focus on comprehension, train your ear to hear the language like a native, and then you will have the tools to train your mouth to mimic it. Ear first, mouth follows. Good luck!

It often creates more headache than it's worth and can work towards burning you out. But if you are super hyped to do so, then do so. Otherwise, wait till you have enough of a foundation that it isn't an undesirable process. Don't force it. Instead, focus on getting more quality immersion.

patterns: what is input
responses: Input is consuming Japanese content. Books, anime, movies, YouTube. Anything made for natives by natives is what we refer to when we say Input in the context of Refold.

patterns: what is output
responses: By output, we mean speaking and writing. Anything that goes from your brain out to the world is output.

patterns: What is Ajatt
What's AJATT
responses: AJATT is **All Japanese All The Time**. This is an old input-based immersion method that was the beginning of immersion becoming popular inside the Japanese Language learning community. The creator of Refold came from AJATT and designed Refold to be a better, more streamlined, efficient and comprehensive method for learning Japanese. Refold takes the core concepts of AJATT and updates all of the details to be better.

patterns: What is slice of life
What is SoL
responses: Slice of Life is a genre of content. It basically means people going about their everyday lives. It's often considered the best domain to master first because it uses everyday vocabulary much more than a show about hunting demons would.

patterns: Steven Krashen

who is Dr. Steven Krashen
Stephen Krashen
who is Stephen Krashen
who is Dr Stephen Krashen
responses: Dr. Stephen Krashen is a champion of input-based language learning methods and creator of **The Input Hypothesis**. He is the most prominent early champion of the foundations we still work off today and has proved its effectiveness.
Field-1: Matt interviews Dr. Krashen and provides a fantastic introduction to immersion learning in the process.

patterns: Am I too old to learn another language
responses: No. Actually, our adult analytical minds provide tools for learning languages we did not have as babies that makes the process go much further. We don't have to immerse 16 waking hours for 10 years to speak like a 10-year-old does. However, the older you are, the harder it will be to obtain a perfect native-level accent and pronunciation, while very young people can still have an easier time with that aspect of language learning.

patterns: Fastest way to learn Japanese
what is the fastest way to learn Japanese
what is the fastest method to learn a language
how to learn fastest
responses: Refold is designed to be the most effective method and will continue to evolve until it is. But, in the end, you need to be honest with yourself. Japanese is a challenging language for people with no similar languages (like Korean) under their belt. It will take a significant investment to reach high levels in the language. I suggest not worrying about how long it will take. Instead, invest an appropriate amount of time every day and enjoy the process. The related question below should provide some more info.
intents.Related-Q: How much should I immerse everyday?

patterns: what is comprehension
responses: Comprehension is understanding the content you are immersing in.

patterns: What is phonology
responses: The system of contrastive relationships among the speech sounds that constitute the fundamental components of a language. Basically, how the language sounds. But I recommend not worrying about it too much till phase 3. Instead, focus on training your ear to hear the sounds through exposure to the language. Focused exposure with intent to understand. Then in stage 3, you can worry more about pronunciation and phonology. Once your ear is properly trained to actually hear the language, you will be equipped to then mimic it.

patterns: Should I follow AJATT
Should I do AJATT
responses: Refold is designed to be the most effective and efficient language learning method in the world. While it's roots come from AJATT, we believe that AJATT is an old, out-of-date, and antiquated language learning method. Many aspects of AJATT are inefficient or unnecessary. You, of course, can read up on AJATT if you want and take whatever lessons you want from that, but in the end, it's not as good as what we are developing here.

patterns: Is Japanese hard
is Japanese a hard language to learn
responses: If you have no experience in other, somewhat related languages (such as Korean), then yes. It can be a challenging language, and you should be prepared for a Marathon. Learn patience and consistency, and you will be fluent. But be impatient and inconsistent, and it will be hard to reach your goals.
intents.Related-Q: How much should I immerse everyday?

Once your instincts are high enough, translating should be a pretty easy skill to develop.

responses: Watching native language content and speaking your native language while learning a second language is fine for most people. It's unrealistic to expect you to cut out your native language from life 100%. The point is to try and continue finding ways to add more Japanese language exposure without negatively impacting things that are more important (such as health, relationships, job, school, etc.). So don't feel guilty about enjoying a movie in English every now and then. Just try your best to get as much exposure as you can. (It won't cause damage per say, but just removes time you could be spending with your Target Language. This time adds up in the long run, so you want to try ur best to remove it as much as you can and replace it with time in your Target Language. But we are all human, so be kind to yourself.)

patterns: What are domains
What is a domain
responses:
Domains are a way to make the language more manageable by breaking it up into smaller pieces to tackle one at a time. The article below should provide all the information you need to know.

Remember, enjoying your immersion is more important than strictly sticking to a single domain. Also, we generally don't recommend worrying about domains till Stage 2C.
Field-1: article on the Refold website covering domains

patterns: Should domains for starting active immersion be kept within the same genre
When should I start worrying about domains
when should I focus on a domain
What are examples of domains
Should I only focus on a single genre
is X concidered a domain
responses:
Until stage 2, we recommend not worrying about domains but just follow whatever interests you most. If you ever get sick of a domain, feel free to stray or widen the domain.

Domains are not hard-coded things, but just a concept we created to help section of the language. Anything could be a domain. Anime would be a very wide domain. Drama, horror, fantasy could all be domains but also somewhat broad. Slice of life is a common first domain as it generally deals with the common language used in everyday speech. High school stories with girl protagonists that take place in Tokyo would be a somewhat small domain. The more narrow your domain, the faster you will feel comfortable in it, and the quicker you will reach that level 4 level 5 comprehension ideal for immersion. But also, the more potential there is for becoming sick of the content. So really balancing this is up to you. How small can you make a domain to make good progress, compared to how motivated can you stay.

As always, remember to prioritize motivation and interest. You will still make progress even if you never stick to a domain. It will just be slower. But slower, enjoyable progress is always better than quicker agonizing progress. And in reality, the fact that you don't enjoy the content anymore will most likely make the more efficient path actually take longer and become less efficient, so don't force a domain too much.

patterns: Why is enjoying the language important
is enjoyment important
Why is there emphasis on enjoyment
responses: This is twofold. First, learning Japanese is a very long process. It will take years before you are ready to start speaking even. The more you enjoy your immersion and time with the language, the more likely you will stick with this very long process. On top of that, language acquisition benefits from focus and engagement. So being into the story, being into your immersion, enjoying your time will actually help speed up the process, and you will be able to remain more focused for longer. Your brain will pin importance on what it's watching and go to work in the background.

patterns: What does it mean to Tolerate Ambiguity
why is tolerating ambiguity so important
why do you put such importance on tolerating ambiguity
responses: Tolerating ambiguity is the acceptance that you won't understand everything. And not only that, but early on, you won't understand A LOT. You must be okay with this. Refold works on finding low-hanging fruit. Hunting down elements of the language that are within your grasp to obtain and understand. To do this, you have to sift through a lot of stuff that is NOT within your range. If you waste time trying to grasp these concepts and understand everything, you will drastically slow down your progress. By accepting ambiguity and being okay with not understanding, you maximize your gains in the language. I've linked an article and a video down below that further explains the importance of accepting ambiguity. This is a crucial concept to understand. I recommend going through both these resources.

patterns: What is the Monolingual Transition
responses: This is the act of transitioning from using the bilingual dictionary to using a monolingual dictionary. I recommend checking out the resources I've linked below for more info.

patterns: When should I do the Monolingual Transition
when is it recomended to do the monolingual transition
when monolingual transition
responses: This is up to you. Refold recommends doing it in stage 2B or 2C. However, you can do it earlier or later. The earlier you do it, the sooner you reap the positive benefits, but the more frustrating it will be. And it CAN be frustrating, that is for sure. The longer you wait, the easier it will be, but you will benefit from its benefits later. In the end, as soon as you are motivated and excited to make the transition, go for it. Even if you start and get sick of it, you can take a break and postpone the rest for later.

patterns: What is comprehensible input
responses: Comprehensible input is the idea that you can understand. It's capable of being understood. While finding comprehensible input that you are interested in is great, it can sometimes be challenging. We don't recommend spending more than a handful of minutes looking for your next piece of content. Hunting for content within your range can sometimes be a big waste of time. If you have some stuff you feel is in your range, go for it, but Refold focuses on finding little chunks of comprehensible input. Sentences here and there. Words here and there. Focus more on finding the content you are interested in and engaged by more so than content in your range. For some people, that interest comes from being comprehensible. For others, it comes from following a subject. Whatever works for you, try and follow it, but don't procrastinate too much by overhunting that perfect piece of content. Volume is essential with immersion. We want A LOT of it.

responses: The core, the foundation of Refold, is immersion learning. Thousands of people and tons of data are proof that immersion learning works. Dr. Stephen Krashen has spent his life promoting the Input Hypothesis. The foundation for all immersion learning methods. While Refold searches to find the best way to apply these language acquisition principles in an easy-to-follow, step by steep process, in the end, it all comes down to immersion. Matt, the creator of Refold, has used immersion to reach incredibly high levels in Japanese, along with thousands of others. If Immersion works is not the question. The question is, how much more can we streamline the process.

That being said, we recommend focusing on 1 somewhat narrow domain at a time, especially early on, to help speed up your progress. Getting more exposure to similar vocab and concepts will accelerate the rate at which you acquire those ideas fully. So focusing in on a narrow domain will help that happen.

patterns: What domain should I try first
what domain should I do first
responses: We generally recommend people do a Slice of Life domain first. Slice of life content typically has vocabulary and speech patterns that more closely resemble everyday speech, so we find it a beneficial first domain. But with that said, never force content. If it is messing with your motivation, find whatever domain works for you.

patterns: What is 2C
why does 2C take so long
how long does 2C take
tell me about the 2c dungeon
tell me about 2C hell
how to pass 2C easily
responses: Stage 2C, other than Stage 4, which is ongoing, is generally by far the longest stage in Refold. This is where you take your comprehension in your first domain from comprehension level 3 up to comprehension 5 or 6. There is a lot of vocabulary, phrases, sentence structures, and more in between you and the end of this stage, so it takes a long time. On top of that, you are learning increasingly less common vocabulary, so you will come across each word you learn less and less often. This can make progress feel non-existent even though, in actuality, you are continuing to make significant progress. It can take years, depending on you and your time invested. Patience is the key to making it through this stage, but know you are not alone. Everyone has to trudge through this desert, and the oasis at the end will be all that more satisfying because of the challenge. Sadly there is not trick to make this stage faster other than, just immerse more.

patterns: How small should a domain be
how much you should shrink your domain
how much should you shrink your domain
how narrow should my domain be
responses: This is kind of up to you. The more narrow your domain, the more likely you will come across the same vocabulary and elements to fully acquire them. However, you also want to make sure you stay motivated and engaged in your immersion rather than mindlessly board with an extremely narrow domain. You will need to find this balance for yourself. In the end, as long as you are spending focused, quality time with the language, you WILL learn it. So don't stress too much about having the perfect domain size. Just have it on your mind and try your best.

patterns: what is snowball effect
what is the snowball effect
responses:
The **snowball effect** is basically the idea that new elements generally become easier to learn and understand as you know more and more of the language. This is because you now have solidified knowledge and memories to attach and relate new info to.

I have linked a video below that covers the **snowball effect** as well as **low hanging fruit** and how this applies to leeches in Anki. While the video covers leeches, this concept applies to many elements of the Refold method and why we make the recommendations.
Field-1: Snowball / Low hanging fruit and more
Goes over the snowball effect, low hanging fruit and how it applies to leeches. Although it applies to many aspects of the process.

responses: 1T (or i+1) sentence, is short for 1 target sentence. It is a concept you don't need to worry about till you start sentence mining in stage 2. It basically is a perfect sentence where you understand everything but 1 element. We hunt these sentences down to slowly chip away, learning new vocabulary in context that we understand once we look up that 1 new element. I've linked a refold article below talking about it, but I would not worry about it too much till you are ready to start sentence mining.

However, if that does not work, then the best thing you can do is just stay quiet about it. Reach a very high level in your language, and if you do that, people will beg you to teach them how you did it. You won't have to convince them of anything. Actions speak louder than words. Happy immersing!

patterns: What words should I add
should i add every words I don't know
how do I know what words to add when sentence mining
responses:
What words to make cards from and add to your Anki is a skill that gets better over time. But in short, there are two things you want to keep in mind.

1. How useful do you think the word is. You can use your instincts on this. Obviously, words dealing with complex surgical procedures if you aren't a surgeon or physics terminology if you don't often talk about or engage in physics content would not be that useful. But if you look at the word, figure out what it means, and feel it's a word worth knowing and could be common, then go ahead and add it. If you were wrong about its usefulness later, you can always suspend/delete the card. Or if you pass it up and feel you are wrong, you can add it later. Any word worth learning, you will come across more than once. So don't worry about missing out on a word.

2. If the above criteria is met, then the next thing you want to consider is, do you feel you will remember it the next time you see it. As you get more of a foundation, you'll start to notice that some words just seem to stick. Or are similar to another word you know, and you may feel you don't need the SRS to remember it. Only add a word to the SRS if you feel you need the SRS to remember it. But if you get the feeling that you might remember it without Anki, then don't add it and instead focus on adding words you feel the benefit from adding to your flashcards.

patterns: does sentence mining count as immersion
is sentence mining immersion
responses: This depends on how you are doing it. If you are using morphman to find sentences (not recommended), then no, this is not immersion. If you sentence mine how we recommend, then yes, it is immersion. Some people see sentence mining as an individual activity. In reality, sentence mining and immersion are one and the same. You don't necessarily want to go into your immersion with a focus on looking for sentences. Instead, you want to focus on understanding your immersion. During that process, you will naturally come across sentences where you think to yourself "Oh man, I almost understood that. What prevented me from understanding it?". In these moments, you can go back and investigate with a dictionary. If the sentence is a perfect 1T sentence, a sentence where you can fully understand it once you know that 1 unknown element, you can add it to Anki. So, in reality, sentence mining is a bi-product of immersion and trying to understand your immersion.
intents.Related-Q: Should I use morphman?

However, if you are motivated to start mining early and find perfect 1T sentence cards, you are more than welcome to start whenever you want. Just be careful about taking on too much too quickly, as learning the tools for sentence mining has a bit of a learning curve.

responses: You should almost always mine sentences. Other than very conreat words like "Red" or "chair", you almost always want the context you encoutnered the word in, and even with concreat words like red, it's probably best to take the sentence anyway just to have it. With that being said, while you always want the sentence, the context, what type of card you make from the data you collect (the word, definition, audio, sentence, etc), is up to you. You can make a vocab card, a sentence card, whatever you want. See related question for more info on the type of cards you can make.

patterns: Do I have to sentence mine
can i just use premade deck
do you need to do sentence mining
is sentence mining nessesary
Do I need to sentence mine
do i need to do sentence mining
responses:
Sentence mining is not essential. Some people don't even ever use Anki, and others will use large premade decks. However, we very much recommend against this and highly recommend sentence mining for many reasons.

1. Avoiding Anki altogether will likely make the process take much longer. Anki is great at priming things in your mind so that you can acquire them faster in immersion.

2. Premade decks, in our experience, are vastly inferior to sentence mining. There are many reasons for this, but here is one main reason. When you sentence mine, you are actively taking words from the content you enjoy. This will increase the likelihood that you will come across those words again sooner rather than later, which also increases the rate at which you will acquire those words. This increases the rate at which your snowball grows (see related questions) and dramatically speeds up your progress. A short investment in learning the tools to sentence mine will pay dividends in the long run and save you a lot of time compared to relying on premade decks too much. (Most also find that sentence mining helps words stick better than finding even the same word in a premade deck because you understand the full context)
intents.Related-Q: What is the snowball effect?  /  How do I sentence mine?

 The current recommended foundation deck is the Refold JP1K deck. Info on this deck is linked below. However, this is for Patron supporters only, so if you need other options, make sure to check out the stage 1 guide or the resource document for alternatives.

responses:
At Refold we recommend you start off with a pre-made foundation deck for the first 1-2k words. After that, you should begin sentence mining your own cards. We do not recommend continuing to use pre-made decks after this initial foundation. However, you can start sentence mining as early as you want. It can be challenging to find proper 1T sentences if you start too early. But if you find a great sentence that you want to mine, feel free to do so.

Careful not to overwhelm yourself with all the sentence mining tools, as there is already so much to learn in the early stages. If you are overwhelmed, fall back on your pre-made deck if you have not learned at least 1k words yet. If Anki is still confusing to you, we also recommend becoming more familiar with the program before venturing out into sentence mining tools.

responses: It is not recommended to do the Refold JP1k deck and RRTK together. RRTK is intended to give you a foundation in kanji. To see kanji as individual characters and not just squiggly lines and prepare you for mastering kanji through vocabulary and reading. JP1K deck, however, was designed to do this in one step. To give you foundation kanji exposure while teaching you vocabulary simultaneously, so you don't have so much front-loaded work before building out your foundation vocabulary. So doing them together would be a waste of time in our opinion.

patterns: Using mnemonics to remember words
mnemonics for vocabulary
should I use mnemonics
responses: This is a personal choice, but our general recommendation is to not worry about mnemonics. The occasional mnemonic that pops into your mind naturally is fine, but wasting too much time trying to create memory tricks to force vocabulary to stick just is not worth the time. This is a strategy that works better for traditional learning, where you hhave to learn informatiion in a specific order and you are tested on it so you have to remember the info that will be on the test. But we feel this slows down your progress in immersion learning. Instead, focus on the words that stick naturally and let the ones that don't stick go for now and try again at a later date. This all plays into our stance on letting leeches leech, low hanging fruit and the snowball effect.

patterns: Should I speak early
should I output early
is it recomended to speak from day one
When should I start outputting
When should I start speaking
Why shouldn't I early output
why do I have to wait so long to speak
What is early output
When should i output
when do I start speaking
responses: Refold recommends focusing on comprehension first and not outputting till stage 3. Early output is the act of speaking or writing Japanese early. Everybody's journey is different, but the general recommendation is to not output until stage 3. There are many reasons we think this is the best route for most people. First, it gives you time to train your ear to properly hear the language. Second, it minimizes bad habits that can form by speaking improperly. Input helps inform good speaking, but speaking does not help inform comprehension or understanding. So focusing on understanding the language first has a double-dip effect helping improve your comprehension and speaking instincts. Trying to speak early does not double dip and is time spent only working on one skill. Speaking. And possibly improperly at that. Suppose you do, however, choose to ignore our advice or are in a situation where you can't wait to output (such as living in the country). In that case, we recommend only speaking with Natives. Two language learners speaking with each other is a recipe for compounding the harmful effects of early output.

patterns: What is Kanji
What is Hiragana
What is Katakana
What is Kana
Whats hiragana
what's hiragana
whats Kanji

whats katakana
what's katakana
what is kana
whats kana
what's kana
how many alphabets are there in japanese
what are the Japanese alphabets
how many alphabets does japanese have
responses:
Japanese has 3 writing systems. Hiragana, Katakana and Kanji. The first two, Hiragana and Katakana (collectivly refered to often as Kana), are phonetic writing systems.

**1. Kana (Hiragana and Katakana)**
 These are phonetic writing systems. This means that each character has a sound, and it's pretty simple, comparatively, to learn how to read and sound out words (much like the English alphabet). While this is not always true, for the most part, Hiragana is used to write Japanese words and form conjugations. In contrast, Katakana is usually used for loan words (words adapted from other languages).

**2. Kanji**
Kanji, on the other hand, is a pictorial writing system. There are thousands of characters, and each character can have multiple meanings and multiple ways of reading them. This is why we recommend learning kanji the way we do. Even if you could import every kanji into your brain, like in The Matrix, you still would not be able to read Japanese. Without a lot of vocabulary knowledge and reading practice, you would not know which reading to use when reading words you don't know. This is because character meanings and readings change based on what word they are used in. This is why we recommend getting familiar with kanji and then actually mastering kanji through vocabulary and reading rather than boring frontloaded " kanji learning".

patterns: Should I learn to handwrite kanji
how do I learn to write kanji
do I need to learn to write kanji
is it okay if I write the kanji out
should I learn to write
should I learn to write japanese
responses:
Refold does not recommend handwriting kanji/kana until after you are fluent. Obviously, if you have a deep drive or reason to do so, go for it. Still, we believe it is less efficient than learning to recognize and read kanji first. You can then focus on writing once your reading comprehension is relatively high.

Learning to write kanji because most communication is done on computers isn't mandatory anymore and is more a personal choice, or for those that live and work in Japan.

Some claim that writing the kanji helps them remember them. While this can be true, the amount of effort and time it takes to do so, we believe, vastly outweighs whatever benefit it might provide. You would get much more benefit just reading and learning more vocabulary.

With that being said, if you want to learn to handwrite kanji, try RTK (Remembering the Kanji), or just keep a handwritten daily journal and lookup stroke order on the fly to learn how to write kanji. Learning calligraphy and how to write kanji beautifully is beyond the scope of Refold. It should be straightforward to research in Japanese once you are fluent.

patterns: How do I learn to read kanji
how do I learn the kanji readings
how do I learn what sounds kanji make
how do you learn to read kanji
Should I learn individual kanji readings
Is it helpful to memorize some readings for kanji
Can I learn some readings for kanji
How can i learn to read kanji with the RRTK
responses:
Refold recommends against any frontloaded Kanji study where you memorize individual kanji meanings and readings out of context. Even if you could import all Kanji meaning and readings into your head, like loading a computer program, you still would not know how to read Japanese. Kanji meanings and readings change significantly based on the word they are being used in, making this out-of-context knowledge not worth the effort and frustration it takes to obtain.

For this reason, we recommend people get a quick and dirty recognition kanji foundation. After this foundation, proceed with the long journey of mastering Kanji through learning vocabulary and reading. Each time you see the Kanji used in a new word, you will further solidify how comfortable you are with the Kanji. Slowly, you will build an instinct for how a Kanji can be read or what it means. Eventually, you will notice you can often guess the reading and meaning of words you had never seen before. This will happen purely off instincts you built up through past vocabulary and reading.
intents.Related-Q: How do you learn kanji?

patterns: How do I know which reading to use
if a word has multiple readings how do I know which to use
if a vocab has more than one reading how do I know which one is correct
how do I know which reading is correct
if a word has multiple readings how do you know which is correct
responses:
If you are asking about individual kanji then ask me "How do I learn to read kanji". If you are asking about vocabulary and how they can sometimes have multiple readings, then here are some of the basics.

Vocabulary can have numerous readings for many reasons. Sometimes one is more formal than the other. Sometimes one is more modern than the other. Sometimes it will actually change the meaning. So how can you tell the difference? There are a few ways.

1. Read the definitions for the multiple readings. If the meaning changes, then figure out which meaning fits the context best.
2. If the meanings are the same, listen to the audio to hear what the native is saying. If you are reading and no audio is available, then I recommend you move on. It's best, especially early on, to move on if you can't find the answer to your questions quickly.
3. If you are at a high level and still can't figure out the difference, try looking for the answer to your question by googling your question IN Japanese. If you arent far enough along to do this yet, then move on and hunt for low-hanging fruit (things that are easily within your grasp). Don't waste time reaching for something you aren't ready to learn yet.
intents.Related-Q: How do I learn to read kanji

patterns: What is RTK
What is RRTK

should I do lazy kanji
